author: Satya Nadella
text:
Our newest AI accelerator Maia 200 is now online in Azure.

Designed for industry-leading inference efficiency, it delivers 30% better performance per dollar than current systems.

And with 10+ PFLOPS FP4 throughput, ~5 PFLOPS FP8, and 216GB HBM3e with 7TB/s of memory bandwidth it's optimized for large-scale AI workloads.

It joins our broader portfolio of CPUs, GPUs, and custom accelerators, giving customers more options to run advanced AI workloads faster and more cost-effectively on Azure.

author: Edward Ongweso Jr
text: Should vibecode something that does a sentiment analysis of Roose‚Äôs AI writing and creates a clock to estimate how close we are to him replicating one of these https://t.co/yTXPlBM6bm

quotedTweet.author: Kevin Roose
quotedTweet.text:
i follow AI adoption pretty closely, and i have never seen such a yawning inside/outside gap. 

people in SF are putting multi-agent claudeswarms in charge of their lives, consulting chatbots before every decision, wireheading to a degree only sci-fi writers dared to imagine.

people elsewhere are still trying to get approval to use Copilot in Teams, if they're using AI at all.

it's possible the early adopter bubble i'm in has always been this intense, but there seems to be a cultural takeoff happening in addition to the technical one. not ideal!

author: Parmita Mishra
text: why are you talking about a Nobel laureate and founder of DeepMind like he‚Äôs some kid no one has heard about üò≠

quotedTweet.author: Podcast Notes üóíÔ∏è
quotedTweet.text:
There's a guy who might be more important than Elon Musk and nobody knows his name.

He's the reason ChatGPT exists. The reason the AI race started. And he just solved a 50-year-old problem that could cure cancer.

This is the story of Demis Hassabis: https://t.co/cUaocZbS3E

author: Ryley Randall
text:
Flying home and I noticed everyone sitting in first class was running clawdbot on a Mac mini with a $200 claude max plan

I looked back and everyone else was running clawd on a $5 vps 

Just an interesting observation https://t.co/2bMzzCuHoV

author: sign√ºll
text:
was talking to someone at a bar in nyc recently.

she was an author, so inevitably given what i do (& against my will) we ended up talking about ai. when i tell you that her idea of it was so dystopian, my god. like she was visibly repulsed by it. not even skeptical. just pure visceral hate. her position was that it should be banned by the government & no one should use it.

this might be half or more of america.

quotedTweet.author: Kevin Roose
quotedTweet.text:
i follow AI adoption pretty closely, and i have never seen such a yawning inside/outside gap.

it's possible the early adopter bubble i'm in has always been this intense, but there seems to be a cultural takeoff happening in addition to the technical one. not ideal!

author: Lisan al Gaib
text: Dario is the first CEO (of the leading AI labs) to speak out about Minnesota and preserving democracy

quotedTweet.author: Dario Amodei
quotedTweet.text: I've been working on this essay for a while, and it is mainly about AI and about the future. But given the horror we're seeing in Minnesota, its emphasis on the importance of preserving democratic values and rights at home is particularly relevant.
